IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To inspire and challenge students to achieve excellence in academics, the arts, athletics and character in a nurturing environment that fosters critical thinking, creativity, accountability to self and others and the discovery of each student's strengths and passions.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The mission of The Stanley Clark School is to inspire and challenge students to achieve excellence in academics, the arts, athletics and character in a nurturing environment that fosters critical thinking, creativity, accountability to self and others and the discovery of each student's strengths and passions.
IRS990.Desc: AT THE STANLEY CLARK SCHOOL (SCS) WE VALUE: - PROVIDING AN OUTSTANDING EDUCATION BY INTEGRATING COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMS OF EXCELLENCE IN ACADEMICS, THE ARTS, PHYSICAL EDUCATION/ATHLETICS AND CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT; - PREPARING STUDENTS FOR HIGHER EDUCATION BY DEVELOPING PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY FOR STUDY SKILLS, CRITICAL THINKING, AND LIFE-LONG LEARNING; - ADMITTING AND RETAINING STUDENTS WHO ARE CAPABLE OF MEETING OUR HIGH ACADEMIC AND BEHAVIORAL EXPECTATIONS SO THAT ALL STUDENTS ARE ENRICHED; - PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF LEADERSHIP QUALITIES; - PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO DISCOVER AND PURSUE THEIR INTERESTS AND TALENTS; - CREATING A NURTURING ENVIRONMENT BY ACTIVELY PROMOTING EMPATHY, MUTUAL RESPECT, AND SERVICE TO OTHERS; - ENCOURAGING WISE DECISION-MAKING SKILLS AND THE ABILITY TO MAKE HEALTHY CHOICES; - PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF HEALTHY SELF-ESTEEM BASED ON AUTHENTIC STUDENT ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND ACHIEVEMENTS; - CREATING DIVERSITY OF CULTURE, RELIGION, ETHNICITY AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC BACKGROUND; AND - FOSTERING THE PARTNERSHIP OF FACULTY, ADMINISTRATION, PARENTS AND STUDENTS AS CRUCIAL TO THE ACHIEVEMENT OF MUTUAL GOALS. THE STANLEY CLARK SCHOOL (SCS) STUDENTS EXCEL IN STANDARDIZED TESTING WITH MOST CLASSES SCORING IN THE 90TH PERCENTILE OR ABOVE. THEY ARE PREPARED TO EXCEL IN HIGH SCHOOL, IN COLLEGE AND IN LIFE - ACADEMICALLY AND PERSONALLY. THEY LEAVE SCS WITH THE ABILITY TO SOLVE PROBLEMS, BE IMAGINATIVE THINKERS, ENTHUSIASTIC LEARNERS AND ADEPT IN EXPRESSING THEIR INDIVIDUAL POINT OF VIEW. THE ARTS ARE ALSO AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE CURRICULUM - AND DAILY LIFE - AT SCS, BEGINNING WITH PRESCHOOL AND CONTINUING THROUGH MIDDLE SCHOOL. THE SCHOOL'S EXTENSIVE ARTS PROGRAM ENHANCES EACH STUDENT'S INHERENT CREATIVE ABILITIES AND FOSTERS THE ABILITY TO PRESENT THEMSELVES AND THEIR WORK WITH CONFIDENCE. "WORK HARD, PLAY HARD" APTLY DESCRIBES A DAY AT SCS. PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND ATHLETICS ARE AN IMPORTANT PART OF EACH STUDENT'S EXPERIENCE. SCS LEARNING IN DEED IS A SERVICE-LEARNING INITIATIVE THAT ENGAGES STUDENTS FROM PRESCHOOL THROUGH EIGHTH GRADE IN HANDS-ON, MEANINGFUL COMMUNITY SERVICE PROJECTS. SCS LEARNING IN DEED COMBINES SERVICE AND LEARNING OBJECTIVES TO: - MEET REAL, DEFINED NEEDS IN OUR COMMUNITY, - PROMOTE STUDENT REFLECTION, - ACQUIRE VALUES, SKILLS, AND PRACTICAL KNOWLEDGE, AND - BRING TO LIFE CIVIC RESPONSIBILITY WHILE GAINING A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF THEMSELVES AND THEIR COMMUNITY. THERE WERE 352 STUDENTS ENROLLED AT SCS FOR THE 2022-23 SCHOOL YEAR. THE STUDENTS COME FROM COMMUNITIES IN AND AROUND SOUTH BEND SUCH AS GRANGER, MISHAWAKA, ELKHART, GOSHEN, PLYMOUTH AND LAPORTE. AN ATTRIBUTE OF THE SCHOOL THAT AFFECTS THE STUDENT POPULATION IS THE LOYALTY OF THE ALUMNI FAMILIES. FOR EXAMPLE, THERE ARE CURRENTLY 43 STUDENTS AT STANLEY CLARK WHO ARE CHILDREN OF ALUMNI, A TESTAMENT TO THE LIFE IMPACT OF THE SCS EXPERIENCE ON ITS GRADUATES.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part V, Line 4 Intended uses of endowment funds
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The organization's endowment funds are intended to supplement the school's operations, i.e. compensation, financial aid, professional development, etc.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part X, Line 2 FIN 48 (ASC 740) footnote
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The School is exempt from income taxes on income from related activities under Section 501(c)(3) of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code and corresponding state tax law. Accordingly, no provision has been made for federal or state income taxes. U.S. GAAP requires that a tax position is recognized as a benefit only if it is "more likely than not" that the tax position would be sustained in a tax examination, with a tax examination being presumed to occur. The amount recognized is the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized on examination. For tax positions not meeting the "more likely than not" test, no tax benefit is recorded. The School's Form 990 has not been subject to examination by the Internal Revenue Service or the state of Indiana for the last three years. The School does not expect the total amount of unrecognized tax benefits to significantly change in the next 12 months. The School recognizes interest and/or penalties related to income tax matters in income tax expense. The School did not have any amounts accrued for interest and penalties at June 30, 2023 and 2022.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part XI, Line 2(d) Other revenues in audited financial statements not in form 990
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: INCREASE IN CSV OF LIFE INSURANCE POLICIES - 2638 uncollectible pledges - -101500

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule D, Part XI, Line 4(b) Other revenues in form 990 not in audited financial statements
Schedule D, Part XII, Line 2(d) Other expenses in audited financial statements not in form 990
Schedule D, Part XII, Line 4(b) Other expenses in form 990 not in audited financial statements
Schedule E, Part I, Line 3 RACIALLY NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The school's non-discrimination policy states: "The Stanley Clark School does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national or ethnic origin, gender, or sexual orientation in administration of its educational policies, admissions policies, scholarship programs and athletic or other school-administered programs."

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Financial applications and tax Form 1040, including supplemental schedules, are required from all students requesting assistance. The Head of School, Director of Finance and Director of Enrollment Management (administration) review and approve all award allocations. All funds are credited to the students' accounts to ensure proper use.

HEAD OF SCHOOL/ASSISTANT SECRETARY, EX-OFFICIO (THROUGH MAY 2021)

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Head of School, Ben Ottenweller, received a housing allowance totaling $17,500 during calendar year 2022. This benefit was treated as taxable compensation to Dr. Ottenweller.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4a Severance or change-of-control payment
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: MELISSA GRUBB (through 5/31/2021) received a transition payment of $117,420 during calendar year 2022. This amount is included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(iii).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: THE FORMER HEAD OF SCHOOL, MELISSA GRUBB, PARTICIPATED IN A SECTION 457(F) NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN prior to her departure in 2021. There were no contributions into this plan during calendar year 2022. Distributions out of this plan during calendar year 2022 totaled $40,000. This amount is included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (B)(iii).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 1a Delegate broad authority to a committee
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Executive Committee shall consist of the President, Vice President, Secretary, Treasurer, and the Chair of each Standing Committee. The Head of the School, ex-officio, and such other Trustees of the Board as may be appointed to the Executive Committee shall be non-voting for the purposes of this committee. A quorum of the Executive Committee shall be necessary in order to transact business. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the officers and the Chairs of the Standing Committees. The Executive Committee shall have the power to act for the Board of Trustees between meetings. None of its acts shall conflict with action taken by the Board. Executive Committee actions shall be reported to the Board at its next meeting. The Executive Committee shall present in writing nominations for the Committee on Trustees to the Board of Trustees at the Annual Meeting.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b Review of form 990 by governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: A final draft of the Form 990, with the exception of a redacted Schedule B for the purpose of preserving the confidentiality of our donors, is presented by our tax advisors to the organization's Finance Committee. Once the Finance Committee reviews, a final draft, excluding Schedule B, is provided to each member of the organization's governing body at a regularly scheduled board meeting. Once reviewed and approved by the governing body, it is then filed with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c Conflict of interest policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Conflict of interest statements are completed by all board members and officers annually and kept on file by the Head of school's assistant. The Board chair and Head of school review the statements for potential conflicts. In the event of a conflict the member does not participate in the deliberations of the transaction.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a Process to establish compensation of top management official
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: An evaluation of the Head of School is performed on an annual basis by the executive committee of the board of trustees. Comparability data is obtained from the National Association of Independent Schools (NAIS) salary comparisons. Written documentation approving any changes in compensation is performed by the Board Chair. The Head of School's performance and fiscal year salary are reviewed and approved at the beginning of the fiscal period. In addition, the Head of School's employment contract is renewed, approved, and signed annually by the board chair.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b Process to establish compensation of other employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The President of the Board of Trustees and the Head of School review the compensation of the Director of Finance on an annual basis . Comparability data is obtained from the National Association of Independent Schools (NAIS) Salary Comparisons. Written documentation approving any changes in compensation is performed by the Board Chair.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19 Required documents available to the public
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Financial statements, governing documents, and conflict of interest policies are not required disclosures pursuant to Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 6104. These documents are not available to the public at this time.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part XI, Line 9 Other changes in net assets or fund balances
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: increase in csv of life insurance policies - 2638; uncollectible pledges - -101500;
